**Australia Passes New Gun and Hate Speech Legislation**
Australian lawmakers passed two bills on Tuesday imposing new gun control measures and further restricting hate speech. This decision comes in response to the mass shooting at Sydney’s Bondi Beach on December 14, where two gunmen inspired by the Islamic State attacked a Hanukkah celebration, resulting in 15 deaths, including a Holocaust survivor and two rabbis, alongside 40 injuries.

Parliament, recalled early from its summer break, approved the firearms bill with a vote of 96 to 45 in the House and 38 to 26 in the Senate. This new legislation establishes a national gun buyback program, the largest since the Port Arthur reforms of 1996, and strengthens background checks for gun licensing.

The hate speech bill, which underwent significant revision ahead of the vote, increased penalties for advocating violence, imposing up to 12 years in prison for religious leaders who incite violence in their official capacities. The legislation also grants the Australian government the authority to ban and restrict organizations deemed to spread hate. The hate speech bill will be reviewed every two years by a parliamentary joint committee, and the opposition will be consulted regarding the listing and delisting of extremist organizations.

The sole surviving gunman, 24-year-old Naveed Akram, has been charged with 59 offenses, including 15 counts of murder and terrorism. The Australian Greens party opposed the hate crime bill, expressing concerns that it could create a “chilling” effect on political speech and debate.

**Markets React to Greenland Tariff Threats**
Markets struggled on Tuesday following President Donald Trump’s tariff announcement targeting eight European countries—Denmark, Norway, Sweden, France, Germany, the U.K., the Netherlands, and Finland—related to their opposition to his Greenland ambitions. The tariffs will start at 10 percent on February 1 and rise to 25 percent on June 1.

As a result of the announcement, the Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 871 points, or 1.8 percent, marking its worst day since October and wiping out its gains for 2026. The S&P; 500 dropped 2.1 percent, while the Nasdaq fell 2.4 percent. European-based stock indices also decreased on the same day, though less dramatically, while gold and silver prices reached record highs.

European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen criticized the tariffs as “a mistake especially between long-standing allies,” and French President Emmanuel Macron described the threats as “unacceptable.” The EU has roughly 93 billion euros worth of retaliatory tariffs prepared but has refrained from utilizing its Anti-Coercion Instrument, seeking a diplomatic resolution.

**Trump Condemns British Chagos Islands Deal**
President Trump criticized the U.K. government over its agreement to cede the Chagos Islands to Mauritius. In a social media post, Trump called the deal “an act of GREAT STUPIDITY” and linked it to his efforts to acquire Greenland, arguing that Britain giving away strategically important land is a major national security concern.

The U.K. and Mauritius signed a treaty in May 2025 transferring sovereignty of the Chagos archipelago while allowing the U.K. to lease the island of Diego Garcia—home to a joint U.S.-U.K. military base—for 99 years. Downing Street defended the deal, asserting that the U.K. will never compromise on its national security.

**Lindsey Halligan Leaves DOJ**
Lindsey Halligan has departed from her position as acting U.S. attorney for the Eastern District of Virginia following a ruling from a federal district judge that her appointment was improper. Attorney General Pam Bondi labeled the circumstances surrounding Halligan’s exit as “deeply misguided.” Earlier this month, a federal judge ordered Halligan to explain why she had retained her title after her disqualification.

During her time, Halligan’s office had filed indictments against high-profile figures, including former FBI Director James Comey and Democratic New York Attorney General Letitia James, though those cases were dismissed after Halligan’s appointment was deemed unlawful.
